revisions.rev:
[[Image:DSC00800 Mike Quade.jpg|thumb|right|alt=Man wearing gray uniform on a baseball infield|[[Mike Quade]] was a manager of the Chicago Cubs]] The [[Chicago Cubs]] are a [[Major League Baseball]] team that plays in the [[National League]] (NL) [[National League Central|Central Division]]. Since their inception as the White Stockings in 1876, the Cubs have employed 56 [[manager (baseball)|manager]]s.<ref name="general BR">{{cite web|url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/teams/CHC/managers.shtml|title=Chicago Cubs Managers|work=[[Baseball-Reference]]|publisher=Sports Reference LLC|accessdate=August 5, 2009}}</ref> The duties of the team manager include team strategy and leadership on and off the field.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://dictionary.reference.com/browse/manager|title=Manager: Definition <nowiki>|</nowiki> Dictionary.com|year=2006|work=Dictionary.Reference.com|publisher=The American Heritage Dictionary of the English Language|accessdate=February 24, 2009}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|title=The Dickson Baseball Dictionary|edition=Third Edition|author=Dickson, P.|page=530|year=2009|publisher=W.W. Norton & Co|isbn=978-0393066814}}</ref> The Cubs have had 13 [[General manager#Sports teams|general managers]].<ref name="GM">{{cite web|url=http://chicago.cubs.mlb.com/chc/history/general_managers.jsp|title=Cubs' General Managers|publisher=[[Major League Baseball]]|accessdate=December 31, 2008}}</ref> The general manager controls player transactions, hiring and firing of the coaching staff, and negotiates with players and agents regarding contracts.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.baseballamerica.com/today/features/051221gmround.html|title=2005 General Manager Roundtable |last=Schwarz|first=Alan|date=December 21, 2005|publisher=Baseball America|accessdate=February 24, 2009}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|title=The Dickson Baseball Dictionary|edition=Third Edition|author=Dickson, P.|page=362|year=2009|publisher=W.W. Norton & Co|isbn=978-0393066814}}</ref> The first person to officially hold the title of general manager for the Cubs was [[Charles Weber]], who assumed the title in 1934.<ref name="GM"/> The franchise's first manager was [[National Baseball Hall of Fame and Museum|Baseball Hall of Famer]] [[Albert Spalding]], who helped the White Stockings become the first [[National League pennant winners 1876â1968|champions]] of the newly formed National League.<ref name="Spalding BR"/>
After co-managing with [[Silver Flint]] during the [[1879 Chicago White Stockings season]], Hall of Famer [[Cap Anson]] began an 18-year managerial tenure in 1880, the longest in franchise history.<ref name="general BR"/> Under Anson, the team won five more NL pennants—in 1880, 1881, 1882, 1885 and 1886—tying the [[1885 World Series]] and losing the [[1886 World Series]] in the process.{{ref label|World Series|a|a}} Anson won 1,283 games as the White Stockings' manager, the most in franchise history.<ref name="general BR"/> After taking over for Hall of Fame manager [[Frank Selee]] in 1905, [[Frank Chance]]—another Hall of Famer—managed the team through the [[1912 Chicago Cubs season|1912 season]].<ref name="general BR"/> During his tenure, the franchise won four more NL pennants in 1906, 1907, 1908, and 1910, winning its only two World Series titles in [[1907 World Series|1907]] and [[1908 World Series|1908]].<ref name="Chance RS"/> Chance's .664 career [[winning percentage]] is the highest of any Cubs manager.<ref name="general BR"/> After Chance, from 1913 through 1960, the Cubs employed nineteen managers, nine of which were inducted into the Hall of Fame. During this period, the Cubs won six more NL pennants, including three under manager [[Charlie Grimm]]. Split between Grimm's two managerial stints in the 1930s and 40s, plus a brief appearance as manager in 1960,<ref name="Grimm BR"/> Grimm accumulated 946 career wins, second-most in franchise history behind Anson.<ref name="general BR"/>
Owner [[Philip K. Wrigley|P. K. Wrigley]] then began experimenting with the managerial position and in December 1960, announced that Cubs would not have only one manager for the [[1961 Chicago Cubs season|coming season]]. Instead, the team implemented a new managerial system known as the "[[College of Coaches]]". The system was meant to blend ideas from several individuals instead of relying on one manager.<ref name="Timline 60s">{{cite web|url=http://chicago.cubs.mlb.com/chc/history/timeline08.jsp|title=Cubs Timeline - 1960s|publisher=[[Major League Baseball]]|accessdate=August 5, 2009}}</ref> During its first year, the team rotated four different managers into the role: [[Vedie Himsl]], [[Harry Craft]], [[El Tappe]] and [[Lou Klein]]. The next year, under the guidance of Tappe, Klein and [[Charlie Metro]], the Cubs lost a franchise-record 103 games.<ref name="team history">{{cite web|url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/teams/CHC/|work=[[Baseball-Reference]]|title=Chicago Cubs Team History & Encyclopedia|publisher=Sports Reference LLC|accessdate=August 5, 2009}}</ref> [[Bob Kennedy]] managed the team for the next three seasons until Hall of Famer [[Leo Durocher]] assumed the managerial role for the [[1966 Chicago Cubs season|1966 season]], effectively ending the five-year-long "College of Coaches" experiment.<ref name="Timline 60s"/> During his first season as manager, Durocher's Cubs tied the franchise's 103-game loss record set four years earlier by the "College";<ref name="team history"/> however, he maintained a winning record for the rest of his seven-year tenure.<ref name="Durocher BR"/>
In the last 37 seasons since Durocher, the Cubs have had 22 managers. [[Jim Frey]] and [[Don Zimmer]] led the team to the [[National League Championship Series]] (NLCS) in 1984 and 1989, respectively.<ref name="general BR"/> In both of those seasons, the team's manager won a [[Manager of the Year Award]].<ref name="MotY">{{cite web|url=http://mlb.mlb.com/mlb/awards/mlb_awards_content.jsp?content=mgr_history|publisher=[[Major League Baseball]]|title=Manager of the Year winners|accessdate=August 4, 2009}}</ref> [[Jim Riggleman]] managed the team for five years from [[1995 Chicago Cubs season|1995]] through [[1999 Chicago Cubs season|1999]], earning the team's first and only [[Wild card (sports)#Major League Baseball|wild card]] playoff spot in [[1998 Chicago Cubs season|1998]]. [[Dusty Baker]]'s Cubs lost in the [[2003 National League Championship Series|2003 NLCS]] during the first year of a four-year managing tenure. Baker's successor, [[Lou Piniella]], led the team to two consecutive National League Central Division titles during his first two years with the team and was awarded the 2008 Manager of the Year Award.<ref name="MotY"/> On July 20, 2010, Piniella announced his intention to retire as manager of the Cubs following the end of the [[2010 Major League Baseball season|season]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/sports/baseball/yankees/2010/07/20/2010-07-20_lou_piniella_former_yankees_manager_and_player_will_retire_as_manager_of_cubs_at.html?r=sports&utm_source=twitterfeed&utm_medium=twitter&utm_campaign=Feed:+nydnrss/sports+(Sports)#ixzz0uFQPXp9i |title=Lou Piniella, former Yankees manager and player, will retire as manager of Cubs at end of season |publisher=Nydailynews.com |date=2010-07-20 |accessdate=2010-08-22 | location=New York | first=Bill | last=Madden}}</ref> However, on August 22, 2010, Piniella announced he will resign after that day's game with the [[Atlanta Braves]], citing family reasons. Third base coach [[Mike Quade]] will finish the rest of the season as manager.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://content.usatoday.com/communities/dailypitch/post/2010/08/cubs-manager-lou-piniella-wont-wait-for-october-to-retire-after-todays-game/1 |title=Cubs manager Lou Piniella won't wait for October, to retire after today's game - Daily Pitch: MLB News, Standings, Schedules & More - USATODAY.com |publisher=Content.usatoday.com |date=2010-01-08 |accessdate=2010-08-22}}</ref> The Cubs' former general manager is [[Jim Hendry]].<ref name="GM"/>
==Table key== </noinclude> {| class="wikitable" |- |<center>'''#'''</center>||A running total of the number of Cubs managers. Any manager who has two or more separate terms is only counted once. |- |<center>'''GM'''</center>||Number of regular season games managed; may not equal sum of wins and losses due to tie games |- |<center>'''W'''</center>||Number of regular season wins in games managed |- |<center>'''L'''</center>||Number of regular season losses in games managed |- |<center>'''Win%'''</center>||[[Winning percentage]]: number of wins divided by number of games managed |- |<center>'''PA'''</center>||[[Major League Baseball postseason|Playoff]] appearances: number of years this manager has led the franchise to the playoffs |- |<center>'''PW'''</center>||Playoff wins: number of wins this manager has accrued in the playoffs |- |<center>'''PL'''</center>||Playoff losses: number of losses this manager has accrued in the playoffs |- |<center>'''PT'''</center>||Playoff ties: number of ties this manager has accrued in the playoffs |- |<center>'''LC'''</center>||League Championships: number of League Championships, or pennants, achieved by the manager |- |<center>'''WS'''</center>||[[World Series]]: number of World Series victories achieved by the manager |- |<center>*</center>||Manager == Managers == [[File:Cap Anson 0555fu.jpg|thumb|right|alt=Baseball card depicting a half-length portrait of a mustachioed man in a blue baseball uniform|[[Cap Anson]] holds the longest tenure in franchise history and won more games than any other [[Chicago Cubs|Cubs]] manager.]] [[File:Frank Chance.jpg|thumb|right|alt=A man wearing a dark-colored coat and baseball cap with his arms crossed stands on a baseball field; two similarly dressed men are behind him.|[[Frank Chance]] led the Cubs to the franchise's only two [[World Series]] Championships in [[1907 World Series|1907]] and [[1908 World Series|1908]].]] [[File:Don Zimmer.jpg|thumb|right|alt=A middle-aged man wearing a light-colored San Diego baseball uniform; the photograph bears a signature saying "Don Zimmer"|[[Don Zimmer]] won the 1989 NL [[Manager of the Year Award]].]] [[File:Dusty Baker.jpg|thumb|right|alt=An older African American man wearing a white, pinstriped baseball uniform and sunglasses; he is autographing a baseball at a baseball game|[[Dusty Baker]] led the team to the [[National League Championship Series|NLCS]] in 2003.]] [[Image:Lou Piniella - 2008 - cropped.jpg|thumb|right|alt=Man wearing a blue baseball uniform walking on a baseball infield|[[Lou Piniella]], [[manager (baseball)|manager]] of the [[Chicago Cubs]] from 2007 to 2010, led the team to consecutive [[National League Central|National League Central Division]] titles in 2007 and 2008.]] ''Statistics current through [[2011 Major League Baseball season|2011 season]]'' {| class="wikitable sortable" style="text-align:center" ! # !! == Notes == *{{note label|World Series|a|a}}The 19th-century World Series was a different event from the current World Series, which was first played in 1903. The 19th-century World Series was considered an exhibition contest between the champion of the [[National League]] and the champion of the [[American Association (19th century)|American Association]].<ref>{{cite web|title=World Series|publisher=[[Major League Baseball]]|url=http://mlb.mlb.com/mlb/history/postseason/mlb_ws.jsp|accessdate=August 4, 2009}}</ref> *{{note label|Frey|b|b}}[[Jim Frey]] won the [[Manager of the Year Award]] for the [[1984 Chicago Cubs season|1984 season]].<ref name="MotY"/> *{{note label|Zimmer|c|c}}[[Don Zimmer]] won the [[Manager of the Year Award]] for the [[1989 Chicago Cubs season|1989 season]].<ref name="MotY"/> *{{note label|Piniella|d|d}}[[Lou Piniella]] won the [[Manager of the Year Award]] for the [[2008 Chicago Cubs season|2008 season]].<ref name="MotY"/>
